info.title: Swedish Company Credit Data
info.description:
Company model for Swedish company credit data. The same model is used for all legalforms, however there are some sections that will be missing for Sole proprietorships and parterships. This will be reflected in the documentation for that section.
Most of the descriptions for the financial items are taken from www.investopedia.com.

SwedishCompanyData.title: CompanyData
SwedishCompanyData.description: This is the root object defining which structures reside under the root path.

CreditLimits.description: Current and historical credit limits as recommended by Bisnode.
CreditLimits.title: CreditLimits

Amount.description: A model describing a monetary value in an amount and a currency. All currencies will be expressed with the ISO standard 4217, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217.
Amount.title: Amount

date.description: Date when the limit was changed/re-calculated.

Inquiry.description: Inquiries are requests generated when a customer makes a credit inquiry on another company or person in order to give the object a loan, a credit or for example sign a rental agreement. The inquiries may be used as a variabel in Bisnode's Rating and Scoring models.
Inquiry.title: Inquiry

Rating.description: Bisnode rating model. More info here: https://www.bisnode.se/kunskap/vara-tankar-om/sa-fungerar-kreditrating/

annualReportDate.description: Date of the annual report data the rating was calculated from.

date.description: Date when the rating was calculated.

code.description: Rating code. [ AAA, AA, A, B, C, AN, - ]

Rating.title: Rating

PartJudgements.description: The rating is based on 4 PartJudgements: AbilityToPay, Finance, Ownership and HistoryOperation. More info here: https://www.bisnode.se/om-bisnode/vad-vi-gor/vart-satt-att-se-pa-risk-och-kredit/kreditvarderingsmodell-foretag/
PartJudgements.title: PartJudgements

max.description: The max value a company can have.

description.description: A textual description of the part judgement.

PaymentIndex.description: A weighted average of the Payment Index of all companies in all industries of the country.
PaymentIndex.title: PaymentIndex

averageDelay.description: Average days of payment delay of invoices (from due date). A negative value means that the invoices are paid before the due date and a positive value that it is payed after the due date.

date.description: Date when this paymentindex score was calculated.

invoiceCount.description: The number of invoices used to calculate the payment index score

invoiceSuppliersCount.description: The number of suppliers that supplied the invoices used to calculate this paymentindex score

paymentIndex.description: The paymentindex score for this company. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paydex for more info on paymentIndex.

paymentIndexAllCompanies.description: The average paymentindex score for all companies in Sweden

paymentIndexLineOfBusiness.description: The average paymentindex score for all companies in the same line of business in Sweden.

count.description: Total number of payment remarks, can differ from the list size which may be capped if there are too many remarks. TODO - max size ???

paymentRemarks.description: A list of remarks, most recent ones comes first. TODO - Max size ???

description.description: A textual description of the event type

Petitions.description: Holder for petitions, the list of petitions may be capped if list is too large. The amount of all petitions is the sum on all petitions currently available in Bisnode's database and may differ from doing a sum on all the petitions in the list.

count.description: Total number of petitions this company have.

Petitions.title: Petitions

Petition.description: A Petition to pay is sent in by the creditor to the Enforcement agency when a debtor does not pay in due time. Reminders can be sent first. The Enforcement agency act on behalf of the creditor, it does not take over the debt. The enforcement agency sends out a letter to the debtor saying that there is a debt which should be paid. The Debtor signs the note and sends it back. The debtor can protest or pay. If protested on, the case is sent to court and credit info companies will not get more information except if there is a default judgement. There are petitions sent to persons but credit info companies does only receive petitions where the debtor are organizations.

description.description: A textual description of the petition, may be in the local language.

Petition.title: Petition

numberOfInquiries.description: Total number of inquiries made on this company

previousInquiries.description: A list of the inquiries. TODO - is there a max size for this?

DebtBalance.description: The debt balance (unpaid debts) registered with the Enforcement agency. The debt is updated once every week and may not be the same as the sum of all payment remarks since some of the remarks may have been paid after debt balance was updated.
DebtBalance.title: DebtBalance

CurrentDebtBalance.description: Claims are split into public claims (A-claims), and private claims (E-claims).

date.description: Date when the claim was submitted to authorities ???

totalClaimsCount.description: Total count of claims including public and private claims.

CurrentDebtBalance.title: CurrentDebtBalance

HistoricalDebtBalance.description: A list of historical debt balances

date.description: year and week number when the debt balance was valid.

HistoricalDebtBalance.title: HistoricalDebtBalance

description.description: A textual description of the event, can be in local language

Events.title: Events
Events.description: Newest events come first. Max xx events. TODO - what is max ???

registrationNumber.description: The national registrationNumber for this company, may be a social security number for Sole proprietors

dunsNumber.description: For foreign companies a duns-number will be supplied instead of the registrationNumber

companies.description: A list of companies that the current company owns a part of.

registrationNumber.description: The national registrationNumber for this company.

parents.description: A list of the parent companies.

ParentCompany.description: A company relates to another one as it's parent if it owns the majority (>50%) of the capital of that other company.

type.description: The parent is either a PARENT (parent 1 level up) or an ULTIMATE_PARENT (top level parent)

ParentCompany.title: Parent

sisterCompanies.description: TODO - should we have this ??? requires some transformation logic since we don't have it today.

SisterCompany.description: A company which is owned by the same parent company as another company. One parent company can have one or many subsidiaries, which all are sister companies to each other.

registrationNumber.description: The national registrationNumber for this company.

SisterCompany.title: SisterCompany

Subsidiary.description: A company relates to another one as it's subsidiary as and when that other company owns the majority (>50%) of the capital of the company in focus.

date.description: TODO - what does this date mean???

Subsidiary.title: Subsidiary

Auditors.description: An auditor is individual who inspects and verifies the accuracy of a company's operational and/or financial records. Public companies are required to use a public accounting firm for the conduct of an audit of their financial statements.
Auditors.title: Auditors

enteredDate.description: Date when this person/entity entered this position.

type.description: What type is this person/entity. I.e is this a private person or a company? TODO - Merge OTHER and UNKNOWN????

name.description: The name of the person/entity holding this position

valid.description: True if the bankgiro account is currently active

numberOfBranches.description: Total number of branches this company have.

formerNames.description: A list of historical names, does not include the current name.

SecondaryName.description: A secondary name (bifirma) is a Swedish trading name, under which a the company can promote part of its business activities.

date.description: The date when this secondary name was registered.

SecondaryName.title: SecondaryName

AlternativeName.description: A name of the company in another language. This is common in countries with more than one official language. The name may not be a translation of a another specific name type like a translation of the Registered name and is thus not the same as "Translated name".

name.description: The name. For more info see: https://bolagsverket.se/ff/foretagsformer/namn/valja/sarskilt-foretagsnamn-och-pa-frammande-sprak-1.2572

date.description: Date when this name was registrered

ContactPoints.description: Methods for getting in contact with this company.

RegisteredAddress.description: The address this company is registered at. may differ from the visiting address.

businessDescription.description: The description registered wth the local authorities describing the companys business.

numberOfAlcoholServicePermits.description: The number of alcohol service permits this company have. See https://sv.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utsk%C3%A4nkningstillst%C3%A5nd

activeInVat.description: If the company is actively paying Vat.

offTheShelfCompany.description: A company which has already been registered by an accountant or lawyer, and which is ready for sale to someone who wants to set up a new company quickly.

registeredAsEmployer.description: 'To have employees a company needs to be registered as an employer at the local tax office. More info here: https://www.skatteverket.se/foretagochorganisationer/arbetsgivare/arbetsgivarregistrering/registreradig.4.18e1b10334ebe8bc80003496.html'

registeredInVatList.description: This indicates if the company is registered according to the Tax VAT register.

Identifiers.description: A set of identifiers for this company.

bisnodeId.description: A unique id set by Bisnode

currentRatio.description:
Current assets in percent of Short term liabilities.
The current ratio is a liquidity ratio that measures whether or not a firm has enough resources to meet its short-term obligations. It compares a firm's current assets to its current liabilities

equityCapitalRatio.description: Calculated equity in percent of the total assets. ???

growthInNetWorth.description: Growth in net value of an organisation's assets, after deducting any liabilities, compared to the result from the previous statement.

growthInTotalCapital.description: Growth in total capital, compared to the result from the previous statement.

growthInTurnover.description: Growth in turnover, compared to the result from the previous statement.

interestCoverage.description: Measures the extent to which interest is covered by earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) plus depreciation.

interestOnLiability.description: Interest on liability expressed in percent

liabilityRatio.description:
Liabilities in percent of equity.
The liabilities to assets (L/A) ratio is a solvency ratio that examines how much of a company's assets are made of liabilities. A ratio of 20 percent means that 20 percent of the company are liabilities.

netSalesTrendIndex.description: The trend for netsales. Comparing this years value with previous year. TODO - Is this percent or what????

profitMargin.description: Operating profit/loss plus financial income as a percentage of turnover.

quickRatio.description: Current assets minus inventories in percent of current liabilities.

returnOnEquity.description: Profit/loss after financial items as a percentage of the total equity.

returnOnTotalAssets.description: Profit/loss after financial items plus financial costs as a percentage of the total capital.

riskMargin.description: Return on total capital minus average interest on liabilities.

statementDate.description: Date when the statement was ??? TODO -

turnoverAssets.description: Capital turnover is measured as profit/loss in relation to assets.

accountPeriod.description: The length in months for the account period

currency.description: Currency expressed with the ISO standard 4217, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217. Applies for all fields in this block containg monetary values.

netSales.description: Net sales - sales from the companys main industry or industries.

changeInInventories.description:
Inventory change is the difference between the inventory totals for the last reporting period and the current reporting period. 
Cost based only

workPerformedForOwnUse.description:
Work performed for own use.
TODO - what does it mean ???
Cost based only

otherOperatingIncome.description: Other operating income includes revenue from all other operating activities which are not related to the principal activities of the company, such as gains/losses from disposals, interest income, dividend income, etc.

totalTurnover.description: The company’s total revenues. Net sales + otherOperatingIncome

costOfGoods.description:
Cost of goods sold (COGS) refers to the direct costs attributable to the production of the goods sold in a company. This amount includes the cost of the materials used in creating the good along with the direct labor costs used to produce the good. It excludes indirect expenses, such as distribution costs and sales force costs.
Function based only

sellingExpenses.description:
Selling expense is reported on the income statement as the sum of all direct and indirect selling expenses of a company. It includes all the costs not directly tied to making a product or performing a service. 
Function based only

administrativeCosts.description:
Administrative expenses/costs are the expenses that an organization incurs not directly tied to a specific function such as manufacturing, production or sales. These expenses are related to the organization as a whole as opposed to an individual department.
Function based only

commoditiesAndNecessities.description:
Raw materials and consumables
Cost based only

goodsForResale.description: Goods for resale are one kind of inventory, but resale goods and inventory are not one in the same. Merchandisers may only have one kind of inventory -- goods to sell to customers -- but a manufacturer includes finished goods, raw materials, supplies and work in process in inventory calculation. Cost based only

otherExternalExpenses.description:
Other external expenses.
Cost based only

staffCosts.description:
'Staff costs naturally include salary costs (including social security contributions) but also Recruitment costs, training costs, Costs for staff health care, pension costs and Business health care costs.
Cost based only'

researchAndDevelopment.description: Research and development (R&D) expenses are associated with the research and development of a company's goods or services. A company generally incurs R&D expenses in the process of finding and creating new products or services.

nonRecurringItems.description: A non-recurring item refers to an entry that appears on a company's financial statements that is unlikely to happen again. It represents a one-time expense involving an unpredictable event and is not part of a firm’s normal, day-to-day operations.

otherOperatingExpenses.description: 'TODO - is this the same as: other expenses not included in nonRecurringItems, researchAndDevelopment, administrativeCosts, costOfGoods and sellingExpenses'

depreciation.description: Depreciation is an accounting method of allocating the cost of a tangible asset over its useful life and is used to account for declines in value. Businesses depreciate long-term assets for both tax and accounting purposes.

totalOperatingExpenses.description: An operating expense is an expense a business incurs through its normal business operations. Often abbreviated as OPEX, operating expenses include rent, equipment, inventory costs, marketing, payroll, insurance, and funds allocated for research and development. One of the typical responsibilities that management must contend with is determining how to reduce operating expenses without significantly affecting a firm's ability to compete with its competitors.

operatingProfitAfterDepreciation.description: Operating profit is an accounting figure that measures the profit earned from a company's ongoing core business operations, thus excluding deductions of interest and taxes. This value also does not include any profit earned from the firm's investments, such as earnings from firms in which the company has partial interest.

resultFromParticipationInGroupCompanies.description: Result from participation in group companies and associated. Example ???

interestIncomeFromGroupCompanies.description: Interest income from group companies. Example ???

otherFinancialIncome.description: Income for a company that comes from anything other than its ordinary operations.

interestExpenseToGroupCompanies.description: 'Interest expenses to group companies. Example: loans'

externalInterestExpenses.description: 'Interest income from group companies. Example: Bank loans ???'

totalInterestExpenses.description:
An interest expense is the cost incurred by an entity for borrowed funds.
Total interest expenses. A sum of externalInterestExpenses and interestExpenseToGroupCompanies. ???

otherFinancialExpenses.description: Other financial expenses not covered by externalInterestExpenses and interestExpenseToGroupCompanies.

totalFinancialCosts.description: Total financial costs. A sum of all costs.

nonRecurringFinancialItems.description: A non-recurring item refers to an entry that appears on a company's financial statements that is unlikely to happen again. It represents a one-time expense involving an unpredictable event and is not part of a firm’s normal, day-to-day operations.

extraordinaryIncome.description: Extraordinary income is an unusual earning that results from unusual circumstances unlikely to be repeated. For example, if a corporation sells off idle real estate, this would generate income for the company, but it would be extraordinary, because it’s unlikely to keep selling real estate on a regular basis.

extraordinaryExpenses.description: Extraordinary expenses is unusual expenses that results from unusual circumstances unlikely to be repeated.

totalExtraordinaryItems.description:
Extraordinary items consisted of gains or losses from events that were unusual and infrequent in nature that were separately classified, presented, and disclosed on companies' financial statements.
extraordinaryIncome - extraordinaryExpenses = totalExtraordinaryItems

resultBeforeAllocations.description: Earnings before appropriations or Result before allocation

shareholdersContribution.description: A shareholder contribution means that any or all shareholders pay money to the company without obtaining new shares. The motive may be that the owners want to avoid the company having to be liquidated.

appropriations.description: TODO - appropriations or allocations ??? Tax law allows companies to wait to pay tax for the year's profit. The rules are designed so that the company should report "pretense costs" if they want to wait for taxation, and report "pretense revenue" the year when they want to tax profits from previous years.

netProfitLoss.description: A positive value means that the company made a net profit and a negative that it made a net loss.

closingPeriod.description: TODO -- set correct type and description

fiscalPeriod.description: Fiscal year-end refers to the completion of a one-year, or 12-month, accounting period. A fiscal year is the period used for calculating annual financial statements. A company's fiscal year may differ from the calendar year, and may not close on December 31 due to the nature of a company's needs.

BalanceSheet.title: BalanceSheet
BalanceSheet.description: A balance sheet is a financial statement that reports a company's assets, liabilities and shareholders' equity at a specific point in time, and provides a basis for computing rates of return and evaluating its capital structure. It is a financial statement that provides a snapshot of what a company owns and owes, as well as the amount invested by shareholders.

Assets.title: Assets
Assets.description: Assets are things that the company owns. They are the resources of the company that have been acquired through transactions, and have future economic value that can be measured and expressed in monetary values. Assets also include costs paid in advance that have not yet expired, such as prepaid advertising, prepaid insurance, prepaid legal fees, and prepaid rent.

workInProgress.description: Work in progress (WIP) refers to partially-completed goods that are still in the production process. These items do not include raw materials or finished goods. Work in progress is usually comprised of the full amount of raw materials required for a product, since that is added at the beginning of production, plus the cost of additional processing as each unit progresses through the various manufacturing steps.

accountsReceivable.description: Accounts receivable is the balance of money due to a firm for goods or services delivered or used but not yet paid for by customers.

receivableFromGroupAndAssociatedCompanie.description: Receivable from group and associated companies.

otherCurrentAssets.description: Other current assets (OCA) is a category of things of value that a company owns, benefits from, or uses to generate income that can be converted into cash within one business cycle. They are referred to as “other” because they are uncommon or insignificant, unlike typical current asset items such as cash, securities, accounts receivable, inventory, and prepaid expenses.

totalCurrentAssets.description: Current assets include cash, cash equivalents, accounts receivable, stock inventory, marketable securities, pre-paid liabilities, and other liquid assets.

CurrentAssets.title: CurrentAssets
CurrentAssets.description: Cash and other resources that are expected to turn to cash or to be used up within one year of the balance sheet date. (If a company's operating cycle is longer than one year, an item is a current asset if it will turn to cash or be used up within the operating cycle.) Current assets are presented in the order of liquidity, i.e., cash, temporary investments, accounts receivable, inventory, supplies, prepaid insurance.

capitalisedCostForRnd.description: Capitalized cost for Research and Development.

intangibleRights.description: Concessions, patents, licenses, trademarks and similar rights.

goodwill.description: Goodwill represents values that arises when you buy a company. If you pay a price that is higher than the value of the assets in the company the remaining amount is concidered as goodwill. Goodwill can be a subject of depreciations. It is an intangible asset.

otherIntangibleAssets.description: These assets could be lease contracts, work in progress, intellectual property rights or anything that is not tangible.

totalIntangibleAssets.description: Total intangible assets. Intangible assets are economic resources that have no physical presence. They include patents, trademarks, copyrights, and goodwill. Accounting for intangible assets differs depending on the type of asset, and they can be either amortized or tested for impairment each year.

landAndBuildings.description: This is property or real estate. There are many kinds of property like land buildings, golf courses, cabins, mining areas etc.

includingLand.description: Land is real estate or property, minus buildings and equipment.

inventory.description: Inventory is the term for the goods available for sale and raw materials used to produce goods available for sale.

otherTangibleAssetsNonDepreciable.description: Tangible assets not being any of the above, and is not a subject for depreciation. For example art or any other item with a remaining value over time. Even fixed assets under production, for example an ongoing construction could be placed here.

otherTangibleFixedAssetsDepreciable.description: Tangible assets that is a subject for depreciation.

sharesInGroupCompaniesAndAssociates.description: Shares in group companies and associated companies.

receivableFromGroupCompaniesAndAssociate.description: Receivable from group and associated companies.

loansToShareholdersAndRelatedParty.description: Loans to shareholders and related party.

totalNonCurrentAssets.description:
Noncurrent assets are a company’s long-term investments where the full value will not be realized within the accounting year. 
  Non-current assets can be considered anything not classified as current.

whereofNotDepreciableNonCurrentCosts.description: Whereof not depreciable non-current costs. Refers to Total non current assets.

NonCurrentAssets.title: NonCurrentAssets
NonCurrentAssets.description: A noncurrent asset is an asset that is not expected to be consumed within one year. If a company has a high proportion of noncurrent to current assets, this can be an indicator of poor liquidity, since a large amount of cash may be needed to support ongoing investments in noncash assets.

Liabilities.title: Liabilities
Liabilities.description: Liabilities are the money that a company owes to outside parties, from bills it has to pay to suppliers to interest on bonds it has issued to creditors to rent, utilities and salaries.

accountsPayable.description: Accounts payable is an accounting entry representing a company's obligation to pay off a short-term debt to its creditors or suppliers.

liabilitiesToGroupCompaniesAndAssociates.description: Short-term liabilities to group companies and associates.

CurrentLiabilities.title: CurrentLiabilities
CurrentLiabilities.description: Current liabilities are a company's debts or obligations that are due within one year or within a normal operating cycle. Furthermore, current liabilities are settled by the use of a current asset, such as cash, or by creating a new current liability.

liabilitiesToGroupCompaniesAndAssociates.description: Long-term liabilities to group companies and associates.

LongTermLiabilities.title: LongTermLiabilities
LongTermLiabilities.description: Long-term liabilities are financial obligations of a company that are due more than one year in the future. The current portion of long-term debt is listed separately to provide a more accurate view of a company's current liquidity and the company’s ability to pay current liabilities as they become due. Long-term liabilities are also called long-term debt or noncurrent liabilities.

shareCapital.description: Share capital refers to funds raised by issuing shares in return for cash or other considerations.

sharePremiumReserve.description: A share premium account is the amount of money paid for a share above the cost of the share.

revaluationReserve.description: Revaluation reserve is an accounting term used when a company creates a line item on its balance sheet to account for asset value fluctuations.

retainedEarnings.description: Retained earnings are the cumulative net earnings or profit of a firm after accounting for dividends.

profitOrlossForTheYear.description: Profit or loss for the year.

ShareholdersEquity.title: ShareholdersEquity
ShareholdersEquity.description: Shareholders' equity is the money attributable to a business' owners, meaning its shareholders. It is also known as "net assets," since it is equivalent to the total assets of a company minus its liabilities, that is, the debt it owes to non-shareholders.

accountPeriod.description: The length in months for the account period

currency.description: Currency expressed with the ISO standard 4217, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217. Applies for all fields in this block containg monetary values.

classificationCode.description:

netWorth.description: Net worth is the amount by which assets exceed liabilities. Net worth is a concept applicable to businesses as a key measure of how much an entity is worth.

quickRatio.description: Current assets minus inventories in percent of current liabilities.

returnOnTotalAssets.description: Profit/loss after financial items plus financial costs as a percentage of the total capital.

netWorth.description: Net worth is the amount by which assets exceed liabilities. Net worth is a concept applicable to businesses as a key measure of how much an entity is worth.

NotesAndOtherInformation.description: Misc information releated to the financial statement

currency.description: Currency expressed with the ISO standard 4217, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217. Applies for all fields in this block containg monetary values.

commentsSecurities.description:
F - Contingent liabilities exist, but amount missing
N - Data not available
Y - Additional contingent liabilities exist but amounts are not specified

commentsLiabilities.description:
F - Contingent liabilities exist, but amount missing
N - Data not available
Y - Additional contingent liabilities exist but amounts are not specified

numberOfEmployees.description: The number of employees at the time of this annual report.

incentiveWagesToEmployees.description: A monetary gift provided to an employee based on performance, which is thought of as one way to entice the employee to continue delivering positive results. Incentive pay may come in the form of a bonus, profit-sharing, or commission.

severancePay.description:
Severance pay is the compensation and/or benefits an employer provides to an employee after employment is over. 
Employers offer packages to employees who are laid off, whose jobs are eliminated because of downsizing, or who retire. Some employees who resign or are fired may also receive a severance package.
